verses.comment: This introduces Elihu's speech, marking a shift from Job’s friends to a younger speaker. Elihu often presents a nuanced perspective on God's justice.

verses.text: "Do you consider this to be justice, when you say, 'My righteousness is greater than God's?'"
verses.comment: Elihu challenges Job's claim of innocence, suggesting that justifying oneself above God diminishes true justice. This foreshadows the church's role in teaching humility before divine authority.

verses.text: "For you ask, 'What advantage does it bring to me? What benefit do I have more than if I had sinned?'"
verses.comment: Job’s questioning echoes humanity’s desire for purpose in righteousness. Elihu suggests our goodness is not transactional with God, nudging readers to pursue holiness for its own sake, not just for reward.

verses.text: "I will answer you and your companions with you."
verses.comment: Elihu declares he will respond not only to Job but also his friends, showing wisdom guided by communal discernment rather than private judgment.

verses.text: "Look up to the heavens and see; observe the clouds, which are higher than you."
verses.comment: Elihu points Job to the majesty of creation, reflecting the transcendent nature of God. This highlights the mystery of divine providence reflected in the order of creation.

verses.text: "If you sin, what effect do you have against Him? And if your offenses are many, what do you do to Him?"
verses.comment: This shows God's transcendence; human actions do not diminish Him. Spiritual interpretation: Even our gravest sins do not threaten God’s majesty but affect our communion with Him.

verses.text: "If you are righteous, what do you give to Him? Or what does He receive from your hand?"
verses.comment: Elihu argues that God does not profit from our righteousness, illustrating that grace is a gift, not earned. The church teaches that works are a response to grace, not a means to manipulate God.

verses.text: "Your wickedness only affects a person like yourself, and your righteousness only benefits other humans."
verses.comment: Human sin and virtue have social consequences; the spiritual reading points to the call for holiness within the community, mirroring sacramental intercession and unity within the people of God.

verses.text: "People cry out because of the multitude of oppressions; they call for help because of the power of the mighty."
verses.comment: This highlights human suffering under injustice and the instinct to call out for deliverance, resembling the faithful’s prayers for God’s intervention.

verses.text: "But no one says, ‘Where is God my Maker, who gives songs in the night?’"
verses.comment: Elihu laments that amid suffering, few seek intimacy with God, the true source of joy. This verse hints at the need for continual worship, even in darkness, a theme central to liturgical prayer.

verses.text: "Who teaches us more than the beasts of the earth and makes us wiser than the birds of the sky?"
verses.comment: God’s wisdom surpasses even nature. Both literal and allegorical readings encourage us to seek divine understanding beyond mere creaturely instinct.

verses.text: "People cry out, but He does not answer because of the pride of evil people."
verses.comment: God’s response is often withheld from the proud, emphasizing the importance of humility. The tradition teaches that true supplication requires a humble spirit and heart.

verses.text: "Surely God does not listen to empty cries, nor does the Almighty regard it."
verses.comment: Insincere prayer is ineffective; authentic, persevering prayer is key. This aligns with the call to continual and communal prayer found throughout scripture.

verses.text: "How much less, when you say you do not see Him—yet your case is before Him, and you must wait for Him."
verses.comment: Patience in suffering is emphasized, pointing toward trusting in God's unseen yet attentive presence. This reflects the tradition of hopeful waiting for God's justice and vindication.

verses.text: "And now, because His anger has not punished, nor has He paid attention to great arrogance,"
verses.comment: God's patience with the arrogant is not indifference; it reflects mercy and an invitation to repentance. The spiritual tradition teaches the necessity of enduring God's timing and mercy.

verses.text: "So Job opens his mouth in vain; he multiplies words without knowledge."
verses.comment: Job's complaints, lacking understanding, are ultimately futile before God's wisdom. Suffering invites us not just to speak but to meditate, seek understanding, and unite our struggles to God's greater purpose.
